conversation.content: [very quietly] Marcus? [pause] I saw your name on the donor list this morning but I thought it had to be a different Marcus Chen, because what are the odds you'd be here after all these years?
Hello, Lily. [clearing throat] The receptionist said my nurse would be someone named L. Chen, but I never imagined it would actually be you working here.

[hesitantly] You're donating platelets for a pediatric cancer patient, according to your intake form. [softly] That's incredibly generous of you, especially since most people don't even know what apheresis is.
[warmly] It's the right thing.

[gently] Well, we should probably get started with the screening questions, though I already know most of your medical history from when we were kids. [pause] Have you had any recent illnesses or taken any medications in the past two weeks?
[quietly] Nothing recent, no.

[professionally] Your arm looks good for the needle placement, strong veins just like Dad's. [softly] The process takes about two hours, and you'll be hooked up to this machine that separates your platelets from the rest of your blood.
[curious] Does it hurt more than regular blood donation? I've been donating whole blood for years but this is my first time doing platelets.

[reassuringly] It's actually quite comfortable once we get started, just a small pinch for the needle. [warmly] Most donors watch movies or read, but the machine makes this rhythmic clicking sound that some people find soothing. [chuckles]
[smiling speaking] Speaking of rhythmic processes, I spend my days now teaching people about wine fermentation and aging, which has its own meditative quality.
Mom mentioned you became a sommelier.
You still talk to Mom? [surprised] She told me you hadn't spoken to anyone in the family for three years after the fight about Dad's treatment. [pause]

[regretful] We reconnected last Christmas when she had that health scare. [very quietly] I realized I'd been punishing everyone for my own guilt about not being able to save him, even though I wasn't even a nurse yet.
[empathetically] You were nineteen, Lily, and watching your father die of leukemia while studying to become a nurse must have been excruciating.
[shaky voice] That's actually why I specialized in apheresis, you know, because platelet donations literally save leukemia patients like Dad could have been saved if we'd had more donors back then.
[softly] Is that why you're emotional about my donation today? [gently] Because the recipient is a child with leukemia, and it's bringing everything back?
[crying while speaking] The little girl you're helping is seven years old, same age you were when Dad first got sick. [sniffle] Her name is Emma and she loves dinosaurs. [pause]
[warmly] Then I'll come back every two weeks for as long as she needs platelets. [very sincerely] Maybe we could grab coffee after one of the sessions, catch up properly?
[relieved] I'd really like that, Marcus, and there's this wine bar near the hospital that just opened if you want to tell me about your sommelier journey sometime.
Only if you promise to explain how this amazing machine works, because watching my blood go out and come back while it keeps the platelets is absolutely fascinating. [chuckles]

scenario: An apheresis nurse recognizes their estranged sibling, now a successful sommelier, as the next blood platelet donor in their treatment room.
